coredata.dc:description: Several n- and p-type Half-Heusler (HH) thermoelectric materials (Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn-based and NbFeSb-based) have been processed by high-pressure torsion (HPT) to improve their thermoelectric performance via a drastic reduction towards ultra-low thermal conductivity. This reduction occurs due to grain refinement and a high concentration of deformation-induced defects, i.e. vacancies and dislocations as inferred by this severe plastic deformation and documented via SEM and TEM investigations. In most cases the figure of merit, ZT, and the thermo-electric conversion efficiency were enhanced up to η ∼ 10% for the thermally stable HPT-processed sample. Raman spectroscopy, backed by DFT calculations, proves that HPT induces a stiffening of the lattice and as a consequence, a blue-shift of the lattice vibrations occurs. Furthermore for all investigated specimens Vickers hardness values after HPT were significantly higher, whereas the change in the elastic moduli was less than 5% in comparison to the HP reference sample.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Several n- and p-type Half-Heusler (HH) thermoelectric materials (Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn-based and NbFeSb-based) have been processed by high-pressure torsion (HPT) to improve their thermoelectric performance via a drastic reduction towards ultra-low thermal conductivity. This reduction occurs due to grain refinement and a high concentration of deformation-induced defects, i.e. vacancies and dislocations as inferred by this severe plastic deformation and documented via SEM and TEM investigations. In most cases the figure of merit, ZT, and the thermo-electric conversion efficiency were enhanced up to η ∼ 10% for the thermally stable HPT-processed sample. Raman spectroscopy, backed by DFT calculations, proves that HPT induces a stiffening of the lattice and as a consequence, a blue-shift of the lattice vibrations occurs.

Furthermore for all investigated specimens Vickers hardness values after HPT were significantly higher, whereas the change in the elastic moduli was less than 5% in comparison to the HP reference sample.

ce:section.ce:para:
With the increasing demand on energy, thermoelectric (TE) generators, which can directly convert (even waste) heat into electricity, gain scientific importance as they can be considered as “green” and sustainable. Besides skutterudites and Zintl phases, Half-Heusler (HH) alloys are the most promising candidates for such TE devices as they have a tunable electronic structure. It can be modified, through doping or substitution on three sublattices and/or through partial filling of the vacant sites in the non-centrosymmetric cubic MgAgAs-type structure (space group
F
4
¯
3 m
). In addition the big advantage of HH-alloys for the production of TE modules and generators is that their starting material, as long as hafnium is avoided, is cheap as well as available and that they can be used in a wide temperature range (from 300 K up to 1200 K). It is worth mentioning that also silicides [1] and PbTe [2–4] have been explored as promising materials for power generation applications.

The thermoelectric performance of TE materials is usually characterized by the dimensionless figure of merit, ZT=S2T/ρλ, where λ = λ e + λph is the total thermal conductivity, consisting of an electronic, λe, and phonon part, λph, S is the Seebeck coefficient, ρ is the electrical resistivity and T is the temperature. For HH-alloys high ZT values of ZT = 0.4 – 1.5 (including those with Hf) were already published in recent review articles [5–9] and Refs. therein and regular articles [10–47]. Although HH-alloys may have a very high power factor, S2/ρ, they suffer from a rather high thermal conductivity, which should be decreased in order to enhance ZT. As the electron part of the thermal conductivity is directly dependent on the electrical conductivity via the Wiedemann-Franz law, it is necessary to distinctly reduce the phonon contribution λph. Besides other routes, an efficient technique is to decrease λph via a drastic reduction of the grain size, and in parallel to enhance the phonon boundary scattering at interfaces and linear crystal defects, like dislocations. One possibility is ball-milling (BM) or high-energy ball milling (HBM), which decreases the grain size and increases the defect density, but during solidification in a hot press or via spark plasma sintering, the grains partially re-grow, and the defect density decreases.

Another route for grain refinement is the high-pressure torsion (HPT) process, as one of the methods of severe plastic deformation [48–51]. Applying HPT, nano-sized ultra-fine grains can be gained together with (i) a high concentration of deformation-induced point and linear defects, mostly vacancies and dislocations, as well as (ii) very thin cracks. These changes in the material occur during HPT-processing when the sample is subjected to a torsional strain under high pressure. To avoid a rather high brittleness, it proved useful to carry out the process under elevated temperatures (about 650 K), but consequently under inert gas to prevent oxidation.

So far, the authors already have carried out very successfully HPT-processing of ball-milled and hot-pressed p- and n-type unfilled [52,53] and filled skutterudites [54–63] and thereby have enhanced ZT of p-type skutterudites to ZT = 1.5 [64] and of n-type to almost ZT = 2 [60]. Although in all cases the electrical resistivity after HPT was higher than that of a simply hot-pressed reference sample, it was possible to reach such high ZT values due to a stable Seebeck coefficient and a strongly decreased thermal conductivity.

Kourov et al. [65] studied the thermoelectric properties of a HPT-processed rapidly quenched Heusler-type alloy Ni2.16Mn0.84Ga. Whilst their investigations helped to get insight into the electronic behavior of Ni2.16Mn0.84Ga, Masuda et al. [66] focused on the thermoelectric performance of HPT-processed VFe2Al-based full Heusler alloys. They reported a figure of merit ZT = 0.3 for VFe2(Ta0.05Al0.95) at around 500 K, which the authors [66] claimed to be currently the highest value among the VFe2Al-based thermoelectric materials.

Encouraged by all these results, in this work n-type HH-alloys (Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02) and p-type HH-alloys (NbFeSb and Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb) (hand- or ball-milled (BM) and hot-pressed (HP)) have been treated by HPT after which their structural, physical and mechanical properties were investigated. The results were compared with those of the respective reference sample before HPT-processing.

As the knowledge of phonon vibrational properties provides a better understanding of the thermal transport behavior of solids, phonon properties were studied employing Raman spectroscopy, which was backed by detailed DFT phonon calculations.

The preparation of the bulk materials, n-type Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn, Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA (DA stands for densification aid) and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 and the bulk p-type NbFeSb and Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb, is described in detail in refs. [41,44]. HP cylinders with 10 mm diameter were cut into several disks of about 1 mm height. A part of such a disk was powdered to determine the structural properties and some disks were cut into proper specimens to measure physical and mechanical properties. All these measurement procedures are described in detail in refs. [43,44,67]. At this stage, all these samples are further on referred to as “HP”.

SEM (scanning electron microscopy) and TEM (transmission electron microscopy) investigations were performed on fracture surfaces and on thin lamellae prepared by focused ion beam, as described in detail in [68].

Two disks of each sample were HPT-processed in a high-pressure torsion equipment (W. Klement, Austria) at 650 K, applying 4 GPa and 1 revolution with 0.2 rpm under argon, the latter to prevent oxidation. These samples are referred to as HP-HPT. Afterwards all procedures and measurements as applied for the HP samples were employed to determine the necessary structural, physical and mechanical properties. Static and dynamic hardness measurements were performed with two different types of equipment (for details see [67]).

Raman active vibration modes were identified by Raman spectroscopy at room temperature with a solid-state argon laser at λ = 532 nm using a LabRAM HR (UV) system equipped with a CCD detector. The spectral resolution is around 0.3 cm−1. A silicon standard, having the Raman peak at 520.5 cm−1 was used for the calibration of the Raman spectrum. All data have been fitted with a Gaussian fit to get the respective peak positions. Based on the methods described in Refs. [69,70], the non-resonance Raman spectrum of ZrNiSn and TiNiSn at 0 GPa and 4 GPa, respectively, were obtained from density-functional theory (DFT) calculations via the plane-wave code VASP [71–73] using the projector augmented wave method. The exchange-correlation potential was treated within the GGA of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerdorfer type [74].

One has to be aware of the fact that HPT-processed samples are not homogeneous with respect to the shear strain, γ = (2πnr)/h, which varies from the center to the rim of the sample, where n is the number of revolutions, r is the radius and h is the thickness of the sample. It is worth mentioning that even in the center (r = 0) of the sample the strain is not zero [75]. With a sample diameter of 10 mm and a thickness of about 0.8 mm, after HPT, γ is decreasing from the rim to the center from about 40 to probably about 0.8. Because of this strain inhomogeneity, it is important to define from which area of the respective disk a sample is taken for the measurement. For simplification, the HPT-processed disk is divided into three sections, rim, middle and center, as outlined in the insert of Fig. 2. The measurements in the ULVAC-ZEM3 equipment required samples with a ∼1 × 2 × 8 mm3 cuboid shape, which covers all three disk areas of the sample. The same applies for the round disk of 6 mm diameter, needed for the measurement of thermal conductivity. For an accurate comparison, Table 1 presents the values of the figure of merit, ZT, and of the thermal-electric conversion efficiency.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electronic and thermoelectric transport properties of n-type half-Heusler alloys

ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 1 displays the X-ray diffraction patterns of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn after various stages of treatment: HP, HPT, and HPT after (measurement induced) annealing. As shown by the enlargement of the (311) reflection at 2θ ∼ 57°, peak broadening occurs after HPT-processing, indicating smaller grain sizes and the presence of dislocations. After annealing, due to grain growth and partially annealing out of the defects, the peak becomes slightly sharper again. These X-ray profile patterns stand exemplarily also for all the other compounds, which were HPT-processed, as the sequences of the peaks’ shapes are always the same, i.e. sharp, slim peak (HP) - broadened peak (HP-HPT) – and finally slightly slimmer (HP-HPT after annealing).

The change in crystallite size and dislocation density is not very spectacular. The crystallite size is for all samples, HP, HP-HPT and HP-HPT annealed, in the range of 34 – 41 nm, whereas the dislocation density changes from 9 × 1014 m−2 to 1 × 1015 m−2.
As can be seen in Fig. 2 , the lattice parameter after HPT-processing is increased, obviously mainly due to fine cracks and various defects, introduced during HPT processing.

After annealing the lattice parameter decreases for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn more than for the samples with DA and those where Sn was substituted by Sb (Table 1). The increase of the lattice parameter after HPT is slightly higher for the rim than for the center area (not shown in Fig. 2). The measured density and - as a consequence - the relative density is lower after HPT-processing and increases, although very little, after the measurement-induced annealing because it seems that more of the small cracks have fused together completely or have transformed into tiny pores.

Fig. 3 represents the calculated Raman shift of TiNiSn, ZrNiSn and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn for a pressure of 0 GPa and 4 GPa (DFT calculations of this work), backed up for better understanding by Fig. 4 . As there are not many Raman spectra of HH-alloys available in the literature and especially none for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn, only a comparison of the spectra of TiNiSn and ZrNiSn with data from the literature is possible. Hermet et al. [76] compared the calculated (GGA and LDA) spectra of TiNiSn with the measured data of Popovic et al. [77] and Mestres et al. [78], and generally found a good agreement. Popovic could assign two strong lines (at 300 K) of TiNiSn to two optical phonon modes, TO1 at 222 cm−1 and TO2 at 254 cm−1, those of ZrNiSn also to two optical modes, TO1 at 199 cm−1 and TO2 at 234 cm−1. In addition Mestres et al. observed for TiNiSn at 80 K a line at 285 cm−1 and assigned it to a longitudinal optical mode, LO2. The LO1 line was calculated by Hermet et al., but it turned out that its intrinsic scattering efficiency was very similar to that of the TO1 line and therefore, due to overlapping, could not be resolved experimentally. One can see in Table 2a that the values of Hermet et al. generally are higher than those calculated in this work, but that also there is a shift towards lower values for ZrNiSn in comparison to TiNiSn. As can be seen in Fig. 3 and Table 2b , Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn provides 6 peaks, all of them shifted to lower values for a pressure of 4 GPa.

Fig. 5 presents the measured Raman shift of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn after hot pressing, after HPT, and after annealing of the HPT sample together with the DFT calculations for 0 GPa and 4 GPa. In the measured Raman spectrum of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn one can see clearly two peaks for the HP sample, one at 197 cm−1 and another one at 238 cm−1, both being in the range of Popov's lines of ZrNiSn. After severe plastic deformation, these two peaks move to higher frequencies (215 cm−1 and 252 cm−1), i.e. almost to the positions of TO1 and TO2 for TiNiSn. Interestingly also at 98 cm−1 a peak for the HP sample appears and shifts to 118 cm−1 after HPT. These results indicate that HPT induces a stiffening of the lattice and as a consequence, a blue-shift of the lattice vibrations occurs.

In order to further understand the Raman spectrum measured, DFT-based Raman calculations were performed. In detail, the crystal structure of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn was constructed by replacing two Ti atoms of TiNiSn (conventional cell, Ti4Ni4Sn4, space group
F
4
¯
3 m
- No. 216) by two Zr atoms (Figs. 4, 5). Data for the lattice, relaxed under 0 GPa and 4 GPa, were calculated. As shown in Fig. 5, there are four peaks, two of them very prominent, in the calculated Raman spectrum under both 0 GPa and 4 GPa. Actually, the four peaks are composed by six frequency values, which are shown in Table 2b for 0 GPa and for 4 GPa. The calculated Raman spectrum for 0 GPa is in fine agreement with the results for the HP sample, however, the peak of the calculated Raman spectrum near 222 cm−1 is much higher than that of the measured one, a fact, which can be explained by the imperfection of experimental samples in contrast to the perfect crystal structure used in DFT calculations. Compared to 0 GPa, the calculation's results under 4 GPa also have a blue shift, which is in line with the HPT results, supporting the fact that HPT induces a stiffening of the lattice.

Fig. 6 displays all values of the electrical resistivity versus temperature, ρ(T), as measured for the HP alloy, and three measurement cycles (from RT up to 823 K and down) of the HP-HPT sample. The HP-sample shows semiconducting behavior, with ρ(T) decreasing with increasing temperature. It should be noted that the first run for the HP-HPT sample (with increasing temperature) gives a completely different picture, because from RT to about 510 K, ρ(T) increases with increasing temperature, and then after a plateau-like maximum, rapidly decreases from more than 5000 μΩcm to about 1200 μΩcm at 823 K, a value, which is even lower than the electrical resistivity of the HP sample at the same temperature. This behavior, reflected in the shape of the temperature dependent resistivity curve, is not unusual, as the HPT-processed skutterudites exhibit about the same dependency [54–62].

Also Masuda et al. [66] published an enhanced resistivity with a maximum for both Heusler alloys, V1.05Fe2Al0.95 and VFe2(Ta0.05Al0.95). For all skutterudites as well as for both Heusler alloys in the work of Masuda et al. [61] the shape of the ρ(T)-curve after annealing follows the shape of the HP ρ(T)-curve, but with higher resistivity values. In contrast to these observations, however, the electrical resistivity of HP-HPT Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn is decreasing with decreasing temperature, indicating metallic-like behavior; in addition, it exhibits again an anomaly at around 640 K, although more smeared-out. This anomaly also occurs in the second measurement with increasing temperature, although even more flattened out. The second measurement still has a hysteresis ρ(T) curve for in- and decreasing temperature.

Finally, the third measurement shows no hysteresis, and an electrical resistivity, which decreases with increasing temperature, with much lower values than those of the HP sample, and a slightly different curvature. These observations indicate that several changes have taken place: the grains grow, stresses are reduced, and some of the cracks fuse together, just to quote the most important changes. It is worth to mention that this process takes much longer than for skutterudites, indicating that the half-Heusler alloy can better preserve the defects being more resistant against heat treatments than skutterudites.

The Seebeck coefficient, S, (Fig. 7 ) is negative, as electrons are the main carriers. The absolute values for all temperature cycles of the HP-HPT sample are much lower than for the HP sample. Except for the first measurement with increasing temperature, all S(T) curves after HPT-processing are, within the error bar, alike. The HP sample shows a prominent maximum, Smax; therefore it was possible to apply the equation of Goldsmid and Sharp [80]
(1)
S max
=
E g
2 e
T max
(e is the elementary charge, and Tmax is the absolute temperature at which Smax occurs) in order to calculate the energy gap Eg of the electronic density of states in the proximity of the Fermi energy, EF. For the third measurement of the HP-HPT sample (referred to as HP-HPT- annealed and considered as thermally stable), the maximum is not very pronounced, revealing a gap in the range of Eg = 157 meV, which appears at a much smaller value than for the HP sample with Eg = 256 meV [41].

For a linear behavior of the S(T) curve, Mott's formula

(kB standing for the Boltzmann constant, and ℏ representing the reduced Planck's constant) can be applied to extract the charge carrier density n, for the simplified case of an effective electron mass m* = me. For the HP-HPT-annealed sample, the slope below 500 K is almost linear, and the number of charge carriers, n, extracted from Eq. (2) is n ∼ 2 × 1021 cm−3.

The power factor, pf = S2/ρ, is displayed in Fig. 8 . The HP sample has a power factor of almost 3 mW/mK2 at around 600 K, however, the values for all measurements of the HP-HPT sample are lower with the highest power factor pf = 2.4 mW/mK2 at 683 K for the thermally stable measurement. The wide hysteresis for the first measurement between in- and decreasing temperature is reduced for the second run and has disappeared completely for the annealed sample (measurement number three). In addition, it is worth mentioning that the maximum of the power factor has shifted to a higher temperature as compared to the HP sample. From Eq. (1) a higher Tmax corresponds to a higher energy gap.

Thermal conductivity was measured for the HP-HPT sample three times with in- and decreasing temperature. For the second and third measurement only the data for increasing temperature are displayed in Fig. 9 , as they were practically alike with those with decreasing temperature. The total thermal conductivity of the HP sample is almost constant below 600 K but increases slightly towards higher T. The HP-HPT sample has practically the same curvature, but the values are lower by more than 30%. For the measurement with decreasing temperature as well as for the second and third measurement, λ(T) is practically stable at about 21 mW/cmK within the entire measured temperature range.

With λ = λph + λe, the lattice thermal conductivity was calculated by subtracting the electronic contribution from λ. The electronic part of the thermal conductivity λe was obtained from the Wiedemann-Franz relation: λ e = L(T)T/ρ(T), where the temperature dependent Lorenz number was derived from Eq. (3):

Here, L is given in 10−8 WΩK−2, and S in μV/K as a satisfactory approximation [81].
The lattice thermal conductivity is decreasing with increasing temperature. It gets quite low for the second measurement but is extremely low for the third measurement.

The temperature dependent ZT values for the HP sample (Fig. 10 ) show a wide maximum of ZT ∼ 0.7 in the range of 673 – 723 K. ZTs for in- and decreasing temperature for three runs are also displayed in Fig. 10. For the first measurement ZT is much lower than ZT of the HP sample, but due to a decreasing electrical resistivity in the second run, for decreasing temperature, ZT is in the same range as ZT of the reference sample, only with a maximum at a higher temperature of 825 K. As for the third run, no hysteresis appears, neither for the electrical resistivity and for Seebeck coefficient, nor in the thermal conductivity data, and the sample can be considered as thermally stable with ZT ∼ 0.8 above 700 K. This corresponds to an enhancement of 15% in comparison to the HP sample.

For practical use not only a high ZT value at a certain temperature is essential but also a high average ZT (ZT)a over a wide temperature regime. The so-called thermo-electric conversion efficiency, η, for power generation is calculated according to equ. (4)

including the Carnot efficiency, where Th and Tc are the temperatures on the hot and cold side respectively. Whilst the HP sample has a high efficiency with η300 – 823 K = 10.1%, the HPT samples (second run) have lower efficiencies, but the stable sample has the same efficiency as the HP sample, and in addition a higher ZT.

Regarding lattice parameters and density, both HH-alloys, Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA, follow the same pattern as was discussed for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn (Fig. 2) although the increase of the lattice parameter for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn after annealing is more prominent.

Physical properties were measured three times, as it was the case for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn, each time with in- and decreasing temperature. Both HP-HPT-processed compounds showed no hysteresis at the third measurement. Therefore, for simplicity, only the results of the measurement for the reference sample (HP), the first measurement with raising temperature of the HPT-processed sample and, after cycling, the results for the “annealed” sample are shown in Figs. 11 –15.

Fig. 11 displays the trend of the temperature dependent electrical resistivities for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA before and after HPT-processing and once more when the samples are annealed. Both HH-alloys have a much higher electrical resistivity after HPT-processing with a prominent maximum at around 600 K. The graphs after three times cycling follow more or less the shape of the reference samples but the values are still higher by up to 25%.

For Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA, there is almost no difference between the absolute values of the Seebeck coefficient of the first measurement and that after cycling, however, in both cases these absolute values are much lower than those for the HP sample (Fig. 12 ), although the difference is not as big as in the case of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn (chapter 3.1.1). The energy gaps have been calculated by means of Eq. (1), as Eg = 228 meV for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 and Eg = 264 meV for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA, being slightly lower after HPT-processing with Eg = 188 meV and Eg = 220 meV, respectively. There is almost no change in the gap after thermal cycling. The number of charge carriers according to Eq. (2) is in the range of 1.25 × 1021 cm−3 for both samples before and after HPT-processing.

The figure of merit ZT, depicted in Fig. 15 , of the annealed HPT-processed Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 with a maximum at 773 K and ZT = 0.93, is higher than that of the HP sample, whereas ZT of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA is lower than before HPT due to a very low power factor and a thermal conductivity not as much suppressed as in case of Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02. The thermal-electric conversion efficiencies for both annealed HPT-processed samples are in the range of 10% (for all η-values see Table 1).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electronic and thermoelectric transport properties of p-type half-Heusler alloys
ce:section.ce:para: We found that semiconducting NbFeSb samples, prepared in the same laboratory, applying exactly the same preparation methods, showing neither in the X-ray spectra nor microprobe analyses differences, still do not have identical transport properties, affecting mainly the temperature dependent Seebeck coefficient and as a consequence ZT. Generally one should point out that there are even larger differences for the various physical properties for NbFeSb samples when comparing data of the current and our recent investigation [44] with those from the literature [10,11,30,82].

SEM images of the fracture surfaces of NbFeSb after HP, after HP-HPT and after annealing the HP-HPT sample are displayed in Fig. 16 . It clearly can be seen that for the HP sample generally a rather bimodal distribution exists with grain sizes reaching from 0.1 to 10 μm. After HPT the grains are heavily deformed, they are cracked and crushed to smaller size, consequently, the grain size of the HPT sample is in the range of 2 μm and smaller. During the annealing process recrystallization takes place, resulting in a fine microstructure, with the majority of the volume filled with submicron grains (Fig. 18, top).

For p-type HH NbFeSb, the lattice parameter as well as the relative density after HPT-processing and after annealing the HPT-processed sample does not change much (Fig. 19 , Table 2). Whilst the lattice parameter slightly increases after HPT and decreases slightly after annealing, the relative density decreases after HPT and after annealing, which is a common behavior for HPT-processed alloys (Tables 2a and 2b).

The values of the electrical resistivity, ρ(T), of the HP sample (Fig. 20 ) are practically the same as those of a previous work of the authors [44]: they decrease with increasing temperature, indicating clearly semiconducting-like behavior. A quite unusual behavior occurs after HPT-processing, in comparison to other HPT-processed samples: although the grains are smaller and additional defects were inserted, the electrical resistivity after HPT is lower than that right after HP; no anomaly in its curvature occurs and the resistivity is decreasing with increasing temperature, even more so after annealing. The reason could be a change of the micro-structure, caused by heating and the strain introduced during HPT-processing. A measurement with a second piece of the HPT-processed sample confirmed these results.

The Seebeck coefficient (Fig. 21 ) of the HP sample changes from negative to positive values around 450 K; after a maximum at 600 K it decreases and becomes negative again above about 750 K. These changes indicate a switch over of the electronic transport from electron to hole dominated conduction and back to electron conduction. This alteration is not only dependent on the temperature but also on changes of the composition within a rather small homogeneity region, indicating that the compound has an electronic structure close to a metal-to-insulator transition. The same temperature dependence of the Seebeck coefficient was also observed in the literature [40,82], however, the maximum of the Seebeck coefficient of the HP sample (Smax = 35 μV/K) is lower than the values obtained in the literature (Smax = 104 μV/K [44] and Smax = 280 μV/K [82]).
It should be noted that also Young et al. [11] and Melnyk et al. [10] claimed negative values for the Seebeck coefficient, at least below 479 K.

After HPT for increasing and decreasing temperature, the Seebeck coefficient does not vary much and for all measurements follows the scheme: negative – positive – negative, as described above, only, the maxima for all these measurements are much lower (Smax = 10 – 16 μV/K). All the measured S(T) curves display a prominent maximum, which allows to calculate the energy gap with the use of Eq. (1). For the HP sample Eg = 41 meV, which is only about one third of Eg of the HP sample of our previous work [44]. The HPT-processed sample shows even lower values with Eg = 20 meV and Eg = 15 meV for the first measurement and the thermally stable one, respectively. These discrepancies are not unusual, as in the literature the experimentally gained and calculated data for the energy gap vary from 20 meV to 1770 meV (as presented in a table of Tavassoli et al. [44]).

Power factors (Fig. 22 ) for the HP sample as well as for the HPT samples are very low, and due to a smaller Seebeck coefficient they are lower than those of the sample from the authors’ previous investigation [44], showing a maximum at around 620 K.

In accordance with literature data [44], the thermal conductivity (Fig. 23 ) of the HP sample is decreasing with increasing temperature. The HPT-processed sample before and after annealing displays a more or less temperature independent thermal conductivity, which is at 400 K about four times lower and at 825 K still about three times lower than the thermal conductivity of the HP sample. Due to a very high electrical resistivity, the phonon part of the thermal conductivity dominates the total thermal conductivity.

All ZT values are very low as can be seen in Fig. 24 and in the insert of Fig. 24. Because of the ultra-low thermal conductivity of the HPT-processed sample, the low power factor is balanced out and the HP and the HPT-processed sample of the first measurement with in- and decreasing temperature show about the same ZT with a maximum around 650 K, a decrease to almost zero and again a relatively high value (ZT = 0.00025) at 825 K. The highest ZT is reached by the annealed HPT sample with ZT = 0.00043 at 623 K, which is an enhancement of about 50% in comparison to the HP sample, but still lower than ZT = 0.0026 from our previous work [44] and that of He et al. [82] with ZT = 0.176 at 773 K. As the HP and HPT-processed pieces stem from the same original sample, one can conclude that severe plastic deformation via HPT could almost double ZT.

In their work Pang et al. [83] describe the phonon vibrational properties of the HH alloy, Ti0.2Nb0.8FeSb, a HH p-type with a composition close to NbFeSb. Using Raman spectroscopy at RT and pressures up to 42.7 GPa, Pang et al. observed for zero pressure one transverse optical mode TO at ∼ 210 cm−1, and one longitudinal optical mode LO at ∼ 260 cm−1. They assigned the TO mode to the motions of Nb/Ti against Fe and Sb and the LO mode as the motion of Fe against Sb. This idea can be well applied to our observations of the Raman modes of NbFeSb (see Fig. 25 ) with two strong peaks at 219 cm−1 (TO) and 282 cm−1 (LO) for the HP sample with a slight move to lower frequencies for the HP-HPT and the annealed HP-HPT sample.

In contrast to NbFeSb, where a new sample was used for HPT-processing, for Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb enough material from a previous investigation [44] was available, so that the HP, the HP-HPT and the HP-HPT annealed sample stem from the same bulk. Like for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02 and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn + DA not all but the most important measured thermal cycle steps after HPT are graphically represented.

Fig. 27 compares SEM images of the fracture surfaces of the HP sample and HPT samples before and after annealing of Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb. The scenario is qualitatively the same for both materials studied, NbFeSb and Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb, however, the changes are slightly more intensive for Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb, displaying a more homogeneous fine recrystallized microstructure after annealing.

TEM investigations (Fig. 28) for Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb revealed not much difference in comparison to NbFeSb for the HP sample with a dislocation density of 3 × 1013 m−2. HPT- processing obviously was more effective for Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb than for NbFeSb resulting in total solution strengthening. This is the reason why the dislocation density is increased by almost two orders of magnitude to 1.3 × 1015 m−2, which is much higher than for NbFeSb. The energy stored in Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb is high enough to cause a complete recrystallization during measurement induced annealing, resulting in a dislocation density of 4 × 1013 m −2 (see also Fig. 18, bottom).
Concerning the changes in the lattice parameter as well as in the relative density, Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb shows the same behavior as undoped NbFeSb (Fig. 19).

The Raman spectrum of Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb (Fig. 26
) shows two peaks at 216 cm−1 (TO) and 281 cm−1 (LO), however, two additional much stronger peaks can be found at 118 cm−1 and 154 cm−1, in agreement with the findings of Popovic et al. [77] who identified them as transverse optical modes.

The electrical resistivity of the HPT-processed Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb (Fig. 29 ) shows the typical behavior of an HPT-processed material, i.e. ρ(T) is higher than for the HP sample, furthermore steeply increasing with increasing temperature, and after a maximum (at 565 K) is rapidly decreasing. For the measurement with decreasing temperature, ρ(T) almost linearly decreases. The second measurement (not displayed) and third measurement reveal metallic behavior with the resistivity increasing with increasing temperature, and values still higher than those of the reference sample.

All measurement points of the temperature dependent Seebeck coefficient Fig. 30 ), HP and HPT-processed, are below 630 K, within the error bar, alike. Above 630 K the S(T) curve of the HP sample continues linearly, whilst all S(T) curves after HPT-processing display a slight downturn after a maximum at about 755 K. Employing Eq. (1) we may thus extract the energy gap with Eg = 250 meV for the HPT sample before and Eg = 245 meV after annealing. Using the linear temperature dependence of S(T) for the annealed sample, the number of charge carriers can be extracted for the HPT sample (Mott's formula ((2)) with n = 1.50 × 1021 cm−3, almost identical with n = 1.56 × 1021 cm−3 for the HP sample [44].

The insert in Fig. 30 describes the temperature dependent power factor. It does not come as a surprise that for all HPT measurements the power factor is lower than for the HP sample, as the Seebeck coefficients are practically alike but the electrical resistivity is much higher.

Thermal conductivity, depicted in Fig. 31 , is (i) decreasing with increasing temperature for the HP sample (75 – 60 mW/cmK for 400 – 823 K), and for the HPT-processed sample before (28.5 – 27 mW/cmK) and after annealing, and is (ii) much lower after HPT-processing.

All ZTs at 823 K of the HPT sample (Fig. 32 ) are higher than the ZT of the HP sample (ZT = 0.68), being ZT = 0.71 and ZT = 0.74 for the first measurement and the annealed sample, respectively. These values are also higher than the ZT of Ti0.16Nb0.84FeSb [31] at 823 K as shown in the insert in Fig. 32.
In respect to further applications of this material as legs of TE generators, mechanical properties, especially hardness and elastic moduli, are an important issue.

Generally there is always a difference in the dynamic and static hardness, with the latter showing higher values. The reason is that with load release the imprint contracts and the diagonals of this contracted imprint are measured, whereas with the dynamic microindenter the geometry of the imprint is registered during loading.

As shown in Table 2, and Figs. 2 and 19, the densities after HPT-processing are decreased. It is a fact that at any fixed temperature the hardness of a material increases with increasing density, but additionally hardness is dependent on the size of the grains. Grain refinement occurs during HPT-processing, as reported in many papers e.g. in Refs. [48,50,55,56,58,66] and as was also visible from the X-ray profiles (not shown) of the n- and p-type HH-alloys of this work.

Looking at the figures Figs. 33 and 34 , it is obvious that hardness appears strongly increased after HPT-processing, however, for both, n- and p-type, hardness depends on the shear strain induced during HPT-processing, i.e. hardness is increasing from the center to the rim of the sample. For p-type NbFeSb and Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb after annealing, when grains have grown, hardness is slightly decreased. Interestingly, for all three n-type HH-alloys hardness after annealing is even higher, although grain growth has taken place. One possible explanation might be that in this case more of the fine cracks have fused together, which resulted in a higher density and hardness.

It was found for various skutterudites that severe plastic deformation has almost no influence on the elastic properties of a material and the values of the elastic moduli before and after HPT-processing are, within the error bar the same [56,59,68,84]. To see whether or not this is also the case for HH alloys, as an example the n-type HH Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn and the p-type HH Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb were measured and discussed. For additional data of elastic moduli before HPT the reader is referred to Refs. [43,67]. For HP Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn resonant ultrasound spectroscopy (RUS) was employed to directly derive the Young modulus E = 164 GPa and the Poisson ratio ν = 0.272 [67]. Using this Poisson number, data for E could be derived from the micro-indenter in parallel with hardness measurements. For the HP sample E = 169 GPa, after HPT processing E increases slightly from the center (E = 170 GPa) to the rim (E = 174 GPa). The changes after annealing are marginal. For Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb Tavassoli et al. [44] derived via RUS E = 192 GPa and ν = 0.281 for the HP sample. With the micro-indenter, using ν = 0.281, for the HP sample E = 195 GPa, for the HP-HPT sample the values are higher with E = 197 GPa at the center, increasing to E = 204 GPa at the rim area. With these measurements we could prove that also for HH alloys after HPT the change in E and as a consequence also in all other elastic moduli is within the error bar of 5% of the value for the respective HP sample.

N- and p-type hot pressed HH-alloys were subjected to severe plastic deformation applying high-pressure torsion. The structural as well as physical and mechanical properties were investigated after HPT-processing and compared with those of the HP reference sample. Generally for all investigated HH-alloys the lattice parameter after HPT increased, whereas the density was lower and so was the energy gap. Raman spectroscopy (backed by DFT calculations) proves that HPT induces a stiffening of the lattice and as a consequence, a blue-shift of the lattice vibrations occurs.

For thermally stable n-type Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn and Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn0.98Sb0.02, the values of ZT and of the thermal-electric conversion efficiency were slightly enhanced (ZT = 0.81 at 773 K with η = 10.1% and ZT = 0.93 at 823 K with η = 10.3%, respectively), however, no ZT enhancement was observed for Ti0.5Zr0.5NiSn with densification aid. For p-type NbFeSb, ZT could be almost doubled, however, ZT of this alloy is generally very low. The p-type Ti0.15Nb0.85FeSb showed an enhancement of ZT from ZT = 0.68 to ZT = 0.75 at 823 K with η = 7.7%. The enhancement of ZT arose mainly from a reduction of thermal conductivity (ultra-low thermal conductivity) due to grain refinement and a high concentration of deformation-induced defects, i.e. vacancies and dislocations (inferred by severe plastic deformation), as documented via SEM and TEM investigations.
For both, n- and p-type HH-alloys the hardness was significantly increased after HPT-processing, whereas the change in the elastic moduli was less than 5% in comparison to the HP sample.
